facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 103 of 1956 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 103 of 1956. J. Umrigar and R. H. Dhebar, for the appellant.

facts.text: The appeal is from the judgment and order of the Madhya Bharat High Court dated February 9, 1955, in Criminal Miscellaneous Application No. 2 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order of the then Madhya Bharat High Court, dated February 9, 1955, in Criminal Miscellaneous Application number 2 of 1954.

facts.text: Originally, the appeal was filed on behalf of the State of Madhya Bharat, now substituted by the State of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: Originally, the appeal was filed on behalf of the State of Madhya Bharat, number substituted by the State of Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: Ganga Ram instituted suit No. 1383 of 1952 against Revashankar for ejectment and arrears of rent in the court of Additional City Civil Judge, Indore.

anchor.surface_text: One Ganga Ram, stated to be the landlord of the respondent Revashankar, instituted a suit, which was numbered as 1383 of 1952 in the companyrt of the Additional City Civil Judge, Indore, for ejectment and arrears of rent against Revashankar.

facts.text: The suit was filed in the name of Ganga Ram and his wife Chandra Mukhi Bai.

anchor.surface_text: It was stated that the suit was filed in the name of Ganga Ram and his wife Chandra Mukhi Bai.

facts.text: Mr. Uma Shankar Chaturvedi advised Ganga Ram to sign the name of his wife Chandra Mukhi Bai though she did not sign the plaint or vakalatnama.

anchor.surface_text: It was further alleged that one Mr. Uma Shankar Chaturvedi, a lawyer acting on behalf of Ganga Ram, advised the latter to sign the name of his wife Chandra Mukhi Bai though Chandra Mukhi Bai herself did number sign the plaint or the vakalatnama.

facts.text: Chandra Mukhi Bai filed an application for permission to prosecute her husband for forgery in the suit.

anchor.surface_text: In this suit Chandra Mukhi Bai filed an application for permission to prosecute her husband for forgery.

facts.text: On June 29, 1953, Revashankar filed a complaint against five persons for offence under s.500 IPC, verified on July 13, 1953, registered as Criminal Case No. 637 of 1953 in court of Mr. N.K. Acharya, Additional District Magistrate, Indore.

anchor.surface_text: On June 29, 1953, Revashankar filed a companyplaint against five persons for an alleged offence under s. 500, Indian Penal Code. This companyplaint was verified on July 13, 1953, and was registered as Criminal Case number 637 of 1953 in the companyrt of one 1374 Mr. N. K. Acharya, Additional District Magistrate, Indore.

facts.text: Mr. Kulkarni appeared on behalf of complainant Revashankar in Criminal Case No. 637/1953.

anchor.surface_text: In that case one Mr. Kulkarni appeared on behalf of the companyplainant Revashankar.

facts.text: Accused persons appeared on August 8, 1953, through Messrs. Mohan Singh and Uma Shankar Chaturvedi.

anchor.surface_text: The accused persons appeared on August 8, 1953, through Messrs. Mohan Singh and Uma Shankar Chaturvedi.

facts.text: Objection raised to appearance of Mr. Kulkarni as his name appeared in the list of witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: An objection was raised on behalf of the accused persons to the appearance of Mr. Kulkarni as the latters name appeared in the list of witnesses.

facts.text: On October 12, 1953, Additional District Magistrate passed order to send copies of applications and affidavits to District Judge for action against lawyers.

anchor.surface_text: This was followed by a spate of applications and companynter applications and on October 12, 1953, the learned Additional District Magistrate passed an order to the effect that the companyies of the applications as well as of the affidavits filed by both parties should be sent to the District Judge for necessary action against the lawyers companycerned.

facts.text: Criminal case No. 644 of 1953 under s.497 IPC started against Revashankar on complaint of Ganga Ram in court of Additional City Magistrate, Circle No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: In the-meantime a criminal case was started against Revashankar in the companyrt of the Additional City Magistrate, Circle No. 2, for an alleged offence under s. 497, Indian Penal Code. The case was started on the companyplaint of Ganga Ram. That case was numbered as 644 of 1953.

facts.text: On December 17, 1953, Revashankar filed an application under s.528 CrPC in court of Additional District Magistrate in Criminal Case No. 637/1953 containing serious aspersions against Magistrate Mr. N.K. Acharya.

anchor.surface_text: We then companye to the crucial date, namely, December 17, 1953. On that date Revashankar filed an application in the companyrt of the Additional District Magistrate who was in seizin of Criminal Case number 637 of 1953. The application purported to be one under s. 528, Code of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: The transfer application alleged that Magistrate wanted to favour Mr. Uma Shankar Chaturvedi based on October 12, 1953 order.

anchor.surface_text: The first aspersion was that from the order dated October 12, 1953 it appeared that Mr. N. K. Acharya wanted to favour Mr. Uma Shankar Chaturvedi.

facts.text: The application asserted that Revashankar would not get impartial justice from the Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: The second aspersion was that from certain opinions expressed by the Magistrate, Revashankar asserted that he was sure that he would number get impartial and legal justice from the Magistrate.

facts.text: The application alleged Magistrate had hand in conspiracy by Mohan Singh and Uma Shankar Chaturvedi to involve Revashankar and brother Sushil Kumar in false theft case of Chandra Mukhi Bai's ornaments.

anchor.surface_text: The third aspersion was of a more serious character and it was that the Magistrate had a hand in a companyspiracy hatched by Messrs. Mohan Singh and Uma Shankar Chaturvedi regarding certain ornaments of Chandra Mukhi Bai with the object of involving, Revashankar and his brother Sushil Kumar in a false case of theft of ornaments.

facts.text: The application alleged Uma Shankar Chaturvedi paid Rs. 500 bribe to Magistrate through Ganga Ram.

anchor.surface_text: The fourth aspersion was that Mr. Uma 1375 Shankar Chaturvedi had declared that he had paid Rs. 500 to the Magistrate through Ganga Ram.

facts.text: The aspersions were repeated in an affidavit filed by Revashankar on December 21, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: These aspersions were later repeated in an affidavit on December 21, 1953.

facts.text: On January 11, 1954, Magistrate Mr. N.K. Acharya reported the facts to Registrar of Madhya Bharat High Court for contempt action against Revashankar.

anchor.surface_text: On January 11, 1954, the learned Magistrate reported the aforesaid facts to the Registrar of the Madhya Bharat High Court, and prayed for necessary action against Revashankar for companytempt of companyrt.

facts.text: High Court issued notice to Revashankar to show cause why action under Contempt of Courts Act, 1952 should not be taken, starting Criminal Miscellaneous Application No. 2 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On this report the High Court directed the issue of numberice to Revashankar to show cause why action should number be taken against him under the Contempt of Courts Act, 1952 and Criminal Miscellaneous Application number 2 of 1954 was accordingly started against Revashankar.

facts.text: On March 3, 1954, Revashankar showed cause in the High Court proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: On March 3, 1954, Revashankar showed cause.

facts.text: On February 9, 1955, Division Bench of High Court (V. Newaskar and S.M. Samvatsar JJ.) held High Court jurisdiction ousted by s.32 Contempt of Courts Act as act constituted offence under s.228 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The case was then heard by a Division Bench companysisting of V. Newaskar and S. M. Samvatsar, JJ. and by an order dated February 9, 1955, the learned Judges held that by reason of the provisions in s. 3 2  of the Act the jurisdiction of the High Court was ousted inasmuch as the act companyplained of companystituted an offence under s. 228 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on September 24, 1958 by K. Das J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. September 24. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS, J.-

facts.text: Magistrate denied knowledge of Revashankar or his brother and characterised aspersion of asking them to make false police report as totally false.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Magistrate characterised the aspersion as totally false and said that he neither knew the respondent number his brother and had numberacquaintance with them.

facts.text: Magistrate stoutly denied the aspersion of taking Rs.500 bribe.

anchor.surface_text: Another aspersion was that the Magistrate had taken a bribe 1381 of Rs. 500. This aspersion was also stoutly denied.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that the aspersions scandalised the court beyond mere personal insult under s.228 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The aspersions made therein prima facie showed that they were much more than a mere insult to the learned Magistrate in effect, they scandalised the Court in such a way as to create distrust in the popular mind and impair the companyfidence of people in Courts.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal and set aside High Court order dated February 9, 1955, holding High Court has jurisdiction.

issues.text: whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the High Court was correct in holding that the act of the respondent complained of constituted an offence under s. 228 of the Indian Penal Code, and the jurisdiction of the High Court was, therefore, ousted by reason of the provision of s. 32 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1952

anchor.surface_text: The sole question arising for determination is whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the High Court was correct in holding that the act of the respondent complained of constituted an offence under s. 228 of the Indian Penal Code, and the jurisdiction of the High Court was, therefore, ousted by reason of the provision of s. 3 2  of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1952.

issues.text: The appeal raises an important question with regard to the interpretation of s. 32 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1952

anchor.surface_text: The appeal raises an important question with regard to the interpretation of s. 32 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1952 (XXXII of 1952), hereinafter referred to as the Act, which repealed the earlier Contempt of Courts Act, 1926 (XII of 1926), as also the Indore Contempt of Courts Act (V of 1930) which was earlier in force in the State of Madhya Bharat.

issues.text: The question for consideration in the present appeal is if the aforesaid view of the High Court is correct

anchor.surface_text: the learned Judges held that by reason of the provisions in s. 32 of the Act the jurisdiction of the High Court was ousted inasmuch as the act complained of constituted an offence under s. 228 of the Indian Penal Code. The question for consideration in the present appeal is if the aforesaid view of the High Court is correct.

issues.text: whether the Magistrate was sitting in any stage of a judicial proceeding when the application and the affidavit were filed

anchor.surface_text: Das J.-It appears that there is a further difficulty in your way, that is, whether the Magistrate was sitting in any stage of a judicial proceeding when the application and the affidavit were filed if he was number, then one of the essential ingredients of s. 228 of the Indian Penal Code was number satisfied.

issues.text: doubts have arisen whether there was any intention to insult, or whether what was said was an insult, or whether the insult was offered in any stage of a judicial proceeding

anchor.surface_text: Umrigar in reply. During the course of discussion, doubts have arisen whether there was any intention to insult, or whether what was said was an insult, or whether the insult was offered in any stage of a judicial proceeding. If any one of these three essentials is lacking, then, obviously, there is number offence under s. 228 of the Indian Penal Code.

issues.text: whether the act complained of is punishable as contempt under any one of the specific provisions of the Indian Penal Code. In other words whether it falls under any one of the sections 175, 178, 179, 180 or 228 of the Indian Penal Code

anchor.surface_text: The question to be considered in this case is whether the act complained of is punishable as contempt under any one of the specific provisions of the Indian Penal Code. In other words whether it falls under any one of the sections 175, 178, 179, 180 or 228 of the Indian Penal Code. If the act complained of constitutes an offence under any of these sections,

issues.text: is the act complained of an offence under s. 228, Indian Penal Code, or is it something more than that

anchor.surface_text: The true test is is the act complained of an offence under s. 228, Indian Penal Code, or is it something more than that ? If in its true nature and effect, the act complained of is really scandalising the court rather than a mere insult, then it is clear that on the ratio of our decision in Ramakrishna Reddy's case the jurisdiction of the High Court is number ousted by reason of the provision in s. 32 of the Act.

arguments.claim: The High Court was incorrect in holding that the act constituted an offence under s.228 IPC and thus ousted its jurisdiction under s.32 Contempt of Courts Act

arguments.claim: Allegations in transfer application and affidavit are not mere personal insult but scandalise the Court creating distrust in public mind

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in coming to this conclusion appears to have relied on two decisions of the Supreme Court--1952 S.C.R. 425 and 1953 S.C.R. 1169. The facts in the two Supreme Court cases were quite different and they do not, in any way justify the view taken by the High Court. It will be my submission that the allegations made in the so-called transfer application as also the affidavit are of such a serious nature that they are not a mere personal insult to the Magistrate, but go far beyond they scandalise the Court in such a manner as to create distrust in the minds of the public, and pollute the stream of justice, and in such cases the jurisdiction of the High Court is not ousted

In the affidavit filed in the High Court in reply to the 1370 show cause notice the respondent had stated that there was nointention to insult or show disrespect to the Magistrate.

arguments.claim: Precedents like Narotam Das v. Emperor support no intention to insult in transfer applications with scandalous allegations

anchor.surface_text: Imam J.-I cannot agree with that, the language used in the application and affidavit is such that intention to insult was clearly there. That may be true, but there are several earlier decisions of the Allahabad High Court which have been referred to in the case relied upon by the High Court-Narotam Das v. The Emperor, A.I.R 1943 All. 97, wherein it was held that where scandalous allegations were incorporated in a transfer application, there was not necessarily an intention to insult, as the primary object was to seek a transfer and not to insult the Court.

arguments.claim: Act is personal insult under s.228 IPC, ousting High Court jurisdiction under s.32

anchor.surface_text: B. Dadachanji and S. N. Andley, for the respondent. The view taken by the High Court is correct and is in accordance with the judgments of the Supreme Court in the cases reported in 1952 S.C.R. and 1953 S.C.R. If the act complained of intentionally offers a personal insult to the Magistrate concerned, it may tend to undermine the administration of justice thereby, but it will nevertheless amount to an offence under s. 228 of the Indian Penal Code and as such the jurisdiction of the High Court will be ousted by s. 3 2  of the Act.

arguments.claim: Every insult to court is contempt punishable under s.228 IPC

anchor.surface_text: It is unsound to say that there are two kinds of contempt, and the lesser kind of contempt will come under s. 228 of the Indian Penal Code and the grosser kind will not come under s. 228 every insult to a Court, whatever its nature, is contempt and punishable under s. 228 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 2  of the Act is in these terms - No High Court shall take cognizance of a contempt alleged to have been committed in respect of a Court subordinate to it where such contempt is an offence punishable under the Indian Penal Code

arguments.claim: Object of contempt is public confidence in justice administration, not personal protection

anchor.surface_text: Mukherjea J. who delivered the judgment of the Court said at page 1176 It would be only repeating what has been said so often by various Judges that the object of contempt proceedings is not to afford protection to Judges personally from imputations to which they may be exposed as individuals it is intended to be a protection to the public

arguments.claim: True test: if act scandalises court rather than mere s.228 insult, s.32 does not oust jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: The true test is is the act complained of an offence under s. 228, Indian Penal Code, or is it something more than that ? If in its true nature and effect, the act complained of is really scandalising the court rather than a mere insult, then it is clear that on the ratio of our decision in Ramakrishna Reddy's case the jurisdiction of the High Court is not ousted

arguments.claim: Intention to insult under s.228 depends on facts; no hard rule for transfer applications

anchor.surface_text: Whether there is an intention to offer insult to the Magistrate trying the case or not must depend on the facts and circumstances of each case and we do not consider it necessary, not advisable, to lay down any inflexible rule thereto.

holdings.text: The learned Judges of the High Court were wrong in holding that the jurisdiction of the High Court was ousted by s.32 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1952 as the act complained of constituted an offence under s.228 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: In that view of the matter s. 32 of the Act did not stand in the way and the learned Judges of the High Court were wrong in their view that the jurisdiction of the High Court was ousted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.32 ousts jurisdiction only where contempt punishable as such under specific IPC provisions (175,178,179,180,228); here act scandalises court beyond mere s.228 insult per precedents Ramakrishna Reddy and Brahma Prakash Sharma.

holdings.text: The aspersions prima facie amount to scandalising the Court beyond a mere personal insult under s.228 IPC, creating distrust in the public mind.

anchor.surface_text: The aspersions made therein prima facie showed that they were much more than a mere insult to the learned Magistrate in effect, they scandalised the Court in such a way as to create distrust in the popular mind and impair the confidence of people in Courts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Allegations of conspiracy to fabricate theft case and bribery attack judicial integrity, impairing public confidence; distinguished from personal insult.

holdings.text: The true test under s.32 is whether the act is an offence under s.228 IPC or something more like scandalising the court; if more, jurisdiction not ousted.

anchor.surface_text: The true test is is the act complained of an offence under s. 228, Indian Penal Code, or is it something more than that ? If in its true nature and effect, the act complained of is really scandalising the court rather than a mere insult, then it is clear that on the ratio of our decision in Ramakrishna Reddy's case the jurisdiction of the High Court is not ousted

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies ratio from Ramakrishna Reddy distinguishing contempt punishable specifically under IPC from other acts scandalising court.

holdings.text: It is not clear if the Magistrate was sitting in any stage of a judicial proceeding when the application and affidavit were filed, lacking ingredient of s.228 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: It is not very clear from the record if the learned Magistrate was sitting in any stage of a judicial proceeding when the application and the affidavit were filed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Record lacks evidence of specific judicial work at filing time; practice varies on filing.

holdings.text: Intention to insult under s.228 IPC must depend on facts and circumstances of each case; no inflexible rule, even for transfer applications.

anchor.surface_text: Whether there is an intention to offer insult to the Magistrate trying the case or not must depend on the facts and circumstances of each case and we do not consider it necessary, not advisable, to lay down any inflexible rule thereto.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Narotam Das; follows earlier Allahabad cases; intention judged case-specifically.

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed; High Court order dated February 9, 1955 set aside; High Court has jurisdiction and must decide on merits.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeal and set aside the order of the High Court dated February 9, 1955. In our view, the High Court had jurisdiction to take cognizance of the act complained of and the case must be decided by the High Court on merits in accordance with law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows jurisdictional holding that s.32 does not apply.

anchor.surface_text: In that view of the matter s. 32 of the Act did not stand in the way and the learned Judges of the High Court were wrong in their view that the jurisdiction of the High Court was ousted.

We accordingly allow the appeal and set aside the order of the High Court dated February 9, 1955. In our view, the High Court had jurisdiction to take companynizance of the act companyplained of and the case must number be decided by the High Court on merits in accordance with law.

The aspersions made therein prima facie showed that they were much more than a mere insult to the learned Magistrate in effect, they scandalised the Court in such a way as to create distrust in the popular mind and impair the confidence of people in Courts.

We accordingly allow the appeal and set aside the order of the High Court dated February 9, 1955. In our view, the High Court had jurisdiction to take companynizance of the act companyplained of and the case must number be decided by the High Court on merits in accordance with law.

edges.explanation: Holding h3 constrains application of c10 by specifying the test: offence under s.228 (in c10) or something more like scandalising.
Holding h3 provides the true test under s.32 for whether jurisdiction is ousted, directly addressing issue i6.

anchor.surface_text: The true test is is the act complained of an offence under s. 228, Indian Penal Code, or is it something more than that ? If in its true nature and effect, the act complained of is really scandalising the court rather than a mere insult, then it is clear that on the ratio of our decision in Ramakrishna Reddy's case the jurisdiction of the High Court is not ousted

We accordingly allow the appeal and set aside the order of the High Court dated February 9, 1955. In our view, the High Court had jurisdiction to take companynizance of the act companyplained of and the case must number be decided by the High Court on merits in accordance with law.
It is not very clear from the record if the learned Magistrate was sitting in any stage of a judicial proceeding when the application and the affidavit were filed.

Whether there is an intention to offer insult to the Magistrate trying the case or not must depend on the facts and circumstances of each case and we do not consider it necessary, not advisable, to lay down any inflexible rule thereto.
